title: Integrative diagnosis of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in non-neutropenic patients using BALF-tNGS–derived Aspergillus load and host risk factors: a multicenter study
source: Frontiers in Cellular and Infection Microbiology | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: BackgroundDiagnosing invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) in non-neutropenic patients is challenging because of non-specific manifestations and limited diagnostic tools. Targeted next-generation sequencing (tNGS) of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) enables rapid pathogen detection; however, its capacity for quantitative assessment of fungal load remains unclear. This study integrated BALF-tNGS fungal load with host risk factors to develop a diagnostic nomogram for IPA in non-neutropenic patients.MethodsNon-neutropenic adults with suspected IPA were retrospectively enrolled at three tertiary hospitals (December 2020–December 2024). IPA was classified according to consensus definitions. Normalized Aspergillus reads from BALF-tNGS were stratified into low, medium, and high tiers. Clinical, radiological, and microbiological variables were analyzed, and a multivariable logistic regression model was built and internally validated via bootstrapping. Diagnostic performance was assessed using receiver operating characteristic analysis.ResultsAmong 238 patients, 134 had IPA and 104 had non-IPA. Compared with non-IPA cases, patients with IPA had higher rates of diabetes (73.9%), corticos
summary: This paper reports on a multicenter study that aimed to develop a diagnostic tool for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in non-neutropenic patients. The study retrospectively analyzed data from 238 patients at three tertiary hospitals, classifying them as either having IPA or non-IPA based on consensus definitions. The researchers used targeted next-generation sequencing (tNGS) of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid to quantify Aspergillus fungal load and combined this with clinical, radiological, and microbiological variables. A multivariable logistic regression model was built and internally validated via bootstrapping to assess diagnostic performance. The results showed that patients with IPA had higher rates of diabetes (73.9%) and corticosteroid use compared to non-IPA cases. The study found that a diagnostic nomogram combining Aspergillus load with host risk factors could accurately diagnose IPA in non-neutropenic patients.  The findings of this study highlight the challenge of diagnosing IPA in non-neutropenic patients, where non-specific manifestations and limited diagnostic tools make it difficult to identify the condition. The use of tNGS to quantify Aspergillus load in BALF provides a potential tool for diagnosis, but its capacity for quantitative assessment remains unclear. The study demonstrates that integrating Aspergillus load with host risk factors, such as diabetes and corticosteroid use, can improve diagnostic accuracy. The results of this study suggest that a diagnostic nomogram could be a useful tool for clinicians to diagnose IPA in non-neutropenic patients.  The entanglement of Aspergillus as a pathogen and a resource is evident in the context of this study. While Aspergillus is a significant threat to human health, particularly in immune-weakened individuals, it can also be a resource for developing diagnostic tools and treatments. The study's focus on developing a diagnostic tool for IPA highlights the complex relationship between humans and nonhumans, where the same species can pose both risks and opportunities.

title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: This paper investigates the degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by the plant-internal microbe fungus Aspergillus bridgerii in a controlled microcosm environment. The study found that Aspergillus bridgerii can cause degradation of the fabric, breaking down its polymeric components. The microcosm used in this study was specifically designed to mimic the conditions found in the human body, allowing for the examination of the fungus's ability to degrade the fabric in a controlled setting. The research suggests that Aspergillus bridgerii can exploit the fabric's material properties, using its enzymatic capabilities to break down the polymer chains and cause degradation. This finding has implications for the development of new materials and technologies for surgical masks, as well as for understanding the interactions between fungi and synthetic materials in various environments. The Patchy Anthropocene lens reveals the tension between the potential benefits of Aspergillus bridgerii as a resource for industrial applications and its capacity as a pathogen to cause harm to human health through the degradation of surgical masks.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: While traditionally the health impacts of the biotic and abiotic components of indoor air have been assumed to be independent, recent studies indicate the opposite, highlighting the need for a systematic evaluation of their interactions to provide a holistic assessment of the health impacts of indoor air. In this study, we assessed the toxicological relationship between a commonly found indoor mold species, Aspergillus fumigatus, and air fresheners, an emerging source of abiotic indoor air pollutants. We evaluated the cytotoxic effects of mold and two air fresheners (Brands A and B) on A549 cells and then tested the effect of co-exposure to the two toxicants on various cellular responses. We also analyzed the chemical composition of the air fresheners using LC-MS. Our results show that both air fresheners were composed of several compounds that could inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. Furthermore, the chemical composition and concentration of the air freshener solutions could influence the toxicological interactions. Overall, our study demonstrates the need for further research on these interactions for a comprehensive assessment of indoor air health impacts. The knowledge will also allow air freshener manufacturers to formulate products with minimal health impacts.
summary: This study examined the toxicological interactions between Aspergillus fumigatus, a common indoor mold species, and two air freshener brands, denoted as A and B. The researchers evaluated the cell-damaging effects of each substance on A549 cells and then tested the effects of co-exposure to both toxicants on cellular responses. The chemical composition of the air fresheners was analyzed using liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry. The results showed that the air fresheners contained compounds that could inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. The study found that the chemical composition and concentration of the air freshener solutions influenced the toxicological interactions between Aspergillus fumigatus and the air fresheners. This research highlights the need for further investigation into the interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air to comprehensively assess health impacts. The findings also have implications for the formulation of air fresheners with minimal health risks.   The study's results reveal a complex material entanglement between a pathogen (Aspergillus fumigatus) and a product intended to improve indoor air quality (air fresheners). While the air fresheners contain compounds that can inhibit mold growth, they also pose health risks to humans, underscoring the need for a nuanced understanding of the relationships between indoor air pollutants and their potential health impacts.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: This paper presents research on the detection and risk assessment of mycotoxins in edible herbs using ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy. The study aims to develop a rapid and reliable method for screening and detecting mycotoxins in edible herbs, which are commonly consumed as fresh or dried products. The researchers investigate the effectiveness of ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy in identifying and quantifying various mycotoxins, including aflatoxins, ochratoxins, and fumonisins, in a range of edible herbs. The study highlights the importance of monitoring mycotoxin contamination in edible herbs to ensure food safety and prevent potential health risks. The results of this research can contribute to the development of more effective and efficient methods for detecting mycotoxins in edible herbs, ultimately improving food safety and reducing the risk of mycotoxin-related health problems.   The findings of this study underscore the dual nature of mycotoxins, which can be present in edible herbs as contaminants but also serve as a marker for the accumulation of human and nonhuman labor, highlighting the complex interplay between human and nonhuman bodies in the production and consumption of food. The use of ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy in this study reveals the intricate material entanglements involved in food production and consumption, where the detection of mycotoxins becomes a matter of negotiating the boundaries between human and nonhuman worlds.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: This study investigated the effects of hyperglycemic conditions on the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol laboratory-based.  hyperglycemic conditions altered the sensitivity of colon cancer cells to these mycotoxins. Specifically, they discovered that hyperglycemic conditions reduced the cell-damaging effects of alternariol and deoxynivalenol on colon cancer cells, suggesting that hyperglycemia may influence the development and progression of colon cancer. The study's findings have implications for understanding the complex interactions between environmental toxins, metabolic conditions, and cancer cell biology. This research highlights the multifaceted relationship between hyperglycemia, mycotoxin exposure, and colon cancer, underscoring the need for further investigation into the underlying mechanisms driving these interactions.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Alternaria alternata causes serious postharvest diseases in tomatoes, threatening shelf life and food safety. In this study, a natural and eco-friendly strategy was developed using Ligusticum jeholense essential oil (LEO), extracted via optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method (EDP-MAHD), which achieved a 3.38-fold higher yield than conventional extraction. GC-MS analysis confirmed consistent chemical composition across production batches. In vitro, LEO exhibited potent antifungal activity against A. alternata (IC₅₀, 0.0718 μL/mL), while in vivo experiments on tomato fruit showed it significantly inhibited lesion expansion and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol (AOH) and tenuazonic acid (TeA). SEM, TEM, proteomic, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress, suggesting multi-target antifungal mechanisms. Acute toxicity in mice confirmed its safety. These findings support the application of LEO as a promising natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.
summary: This study investigated the antifungal properties of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata, a fungus that causes serious postharvest diseases in tomatoes. LEO was extracted using an optimized method that produced a 3.38-fold higher yield than conventional methods. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis confirmed consistent chemical composition across production batches. laboratory experiments showed that LEO exhibited potent antifungal activity against A. alternata, with an IC₅₀ of 0.0718 μL/mL. live-organism experiments on tomato fruit demonstrated that LEO substantially reduced the spread of damage and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol and tenuazonic acid (TeA). Scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, protein-level analysis, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress, suggesting multi-target antifungal mechanisms. Acute toxicity tests in mice confirmed the safety of LEO. These findings suggest that LEO could be used as a natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.  The antifungal properties of LEO against A. alternata highlight its potential as a natural remedy for postharvest disease in tomatoes. However, this study also underscores the complex and multifaceted relationships between fungi, plants, and their environment. The fact that LEO disrupts membrane integrity and interferes with energy metabolism in A. alternata suggests that this fungus is not simply a pathogen, but rather a complex organism that interacts with its environment in multiple ways. This tension between the potential benefits and risks of using LEO as a natural preservative raises important questions about the long-term consequences of relying on such strategies for disease control.

title: Advances in affinity magnetic bead - based pretreatment and detection strategies for mycotoxins in foods: A review
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 15 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 508, Part AAuthor(s): Jinnan Chen, Jin Ye, Hongmei Liu, Shuangshou Wang, Daojin Li, Haihua Ma, Songxue Wang
summary: This paper discusses advances in using affinity magnetic bead-based methods for detecting mycotoxins in food. The approach involves a two-step process: pretreatment and detection. The pretreatment step uses affinity magnetic beads to selectively bind to mycotoxins, allowing for their removal from the food sample. This is followed by a detection step, where the remaining mycotoxins are quantified using various techniques. The review highlights the importance of accurate and efficient detection of mycotoxins in food, as they can have adverse effects on human health and the economy.   The findings in this paper reveal the potential of affinity magnetic bead-based methods to improve mycotoxin detection, particularly in complex food matrices. This technology may be useful for identifying and removing mycotoxins from contaminated food products, thereby reducing the risk of exposure to these toxins. The research highlights the duality of mycotoxins as contaminants and as targets for remediation, underscoring the complex material entanglements involved in food production and consumption.

title: Antimicrobial, anticancer activities and molecular docking of eco-friendly chitosan nanocapsule loaded with biosynthesized titanium nanoparticles by Aspergillus flavus
source: Frontiers in Microbiology | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionChitosan have been leveraged to create chitosan nanocapsules within a bio-based nanocarrier system, enhancing efficacy and overcoming widespread microbial resistance. To generate chitosan nanocapsules (CNCs) that act as inhibitory agents against pathogenic microbes, this study combined titanium nanoparticles (TiO2 NPs) with chitosan nanoparticles (Cs NPs).MethodsA.flavus was used for the biosynthesis of TiO2NPs. Dynamic light scattering (DLS), zeta potential, atomic force microscopy (AFM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD), were utilized to assess the physicochemical properties of TiO2NPs and their CNCs. These techniques clarified particle diameter, charge stability, specific surface area, surface morphology, shape, dimensional forms, and structural parameters, respectively.ResultsThe findings showed that TiO2NPs and their nanocapsules achieved an encapsulation efficacy of over 86.7 ± 1.8% at 1.5% w/v chitosan concentration, with particle sizes of 40.7, 40.6, and 87.3 nm for TiO2NPs, CsNPs, and CNCs, respectively. Nanoparticle stability was confirmed by a zeta potential greater than –30.1 ± 4.5mV for T
summary: The findings of this study describe the creation and characterization of chitosan nanocapsules loaded with biosynthesized titanium nanoparticles by Aspergillus flavus. The researchers used dynamic light scattering, zeta potential, atomic force microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and X-ray diffraction to assess the physicochemical properties of the titanium nanoparticles and the resulting nanocapsules. The results showed that the titanium nanoparticles and their nanocapsules achieved an encapsulation efficacy of over 86.7% at a chitosan concentration of 1.5% w/v, with particle sizes of 40.7, 40.6, and 87.3 nm for the titanium nanoparticles, chitosan nanoparticles, and nanocapsules, respectively.  The stability of the nanoparticles was confirmed by a zeta potential greater than -30.1 mV. The researchers suggest that these chitosan nanocapsules loaded with titanium nanoparticles could act as inhibitory agents against pathogenic microbes, including those that are resistant to conventional antibiotics.   the potential of using biosynthesized nanoparticles and chitosan nanocapsules as a novel approach to combat microbial infections. The findings demonstrate the feasibility of creating effective antimicrobial agents through the combination of titanium nanoparticles and chitosan nanocapsules. The material entanglement between titanium nanoparticles and chitosan nanocapsules reveals a nuanced relationship between biotic and abiotic materials, where a pathogen can also be a resource for remediation.

title: Cyclic lipopeptides from Bacillus amyloliquefaciens D-1 control leaf spot in Pseudostellaria heterophylla via enhancing host immunity and inhibiting Alternaria alternata
source: Frontiers in Microbiology | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionPseudostellaria heterophylla, a valuable medicinal herb in traditional Chinese medicine, is severely threatened by leaf spot disease caused by Alternaria alternata, leading to significant yield losses and mycotoxin contamination that compromises root quality and safety. This study aimed to characterize Bacillus amyloliquefaciens strain D-1 as a potential multifunctional biocontrol agent to mitigate this pathogen.MethodsStrain D-1 was isolated from the rhizosphere soil of P. heterophylla. Its antifungal efficacy was assessed through in vitro dual-culture assays and in planta pot experiments using both viable cells (Bc) and cell-free fermentation supernatant (Bf). Whole-genome sequencing was employed to identify biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs), and high-performance liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (HPLC-MS) was used to detect lipopeptides (LPs). Quantitative PCR and mycotoxin quantification were performed to evaluate the effects on fungal gene expression and toxin accumulation.ResultsStrain D-1 demonstrated strong antagonistic activity, with Bf achieving a 54.7% inhibition rate against A. alternata. Genomic analysis revealed nine putative BGCs, including those fo
summary: This study investigates the potential of Bacillus amyloliquefaciens strain D-1 as a biocontrol agent against leaf spot disease in Pseudostellaria heterophylla, a medicinal herb threatened by Alternaria alternata. The strain was isolated from the root zone soil of P. heterophylla and demonstrated strong antifungal efficacy, with its cell-free fermentation supernatant achieving a 54.7% inhibition rate against A. alternata in laboratory-based dual-culture assays and in planta pot experiments. Whole-genome sequencing revealed nine putative biosynthetic gene clusters, including those for lipopeptide production, which were detected using high-performance liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry. The study suggests that strain D-1 enhances host immunity and inhibits Alternaria alternata, providing a potential multifunctional biocontrol strategy for mitigating leaf spot disease in P. heterophylla.  The findings highlight the potential of Bacillus amyloliquefaciens as a biocontrol agent, leveraging its capacity to enhance host immunity and inhibit fungal pathogens. The material entanglement between the bacterium, the plant, and the pathogen underscores the intricate relationships within this ecological assemblage, where a biocontrol agent can also serve as a resource for plant health and disease mitigation.

title: A novel internal reference microorganism-based method reveals wild-enriched Penicillium for enhancing growth and disease resistance in Fritillaria thunbergii
source: Frontiers in Microbiology | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionFritillaria thunbergii Miq. is an important traditional Chinese medicinal herb, but bulb rot disease causes severe losses during its cultivation. Screening and reintroducing beneficial microorganisms from the wild rhizosphere is an effective strategy to increase disease resistance in cultivated plants. However, the absolute quantitative characteristics of microorganisms cannot be reflected by traditional methods based on relative abundance analysis due to compositional bias.MethodsIn this study, we identified Clavatospora as a host-specific internal reference microorganism (IRM) and established an IRM-based relative abundance differential microorganism analysis (IRMRADMA) method.ResultsApplication of this method revealed that wild F. thunbergii possesses greater potential than cultivated plants for mining beneficial rhizosphere microorganisms. Specifically, Penicillium was identified as a key wild-enriched genus. Subsequently, two strains, Penicillium korosum and Penicillium aculeatum, were isolated from the rhizosphere of wild F. thunbergii. Functional tests confirmed that these strains demonstrated dual functions in disease suppression and plant growth promotion by so
summary: This paper presents a novel method, IRM-based relative abundance differential microorganism analysis, which utilizes a host-specific internal reference microorganism to quantify the absolute abundance of microorganisms in the root zone of Fritillaria thunbergii. The researchers identified Clavatospora as the IRM and applied this method to compare the root zone microorganisms of wild and cultivated F. thunbergii. The findings revealed that wild F. thunbergii possesses a greater potential for mining beneficial root zone microorganisms, with Penicillium being a key wild-enriched genus. Two strains of Penicillium, korosum and aculeatum, were isolated and found to exhibit dual functions in disease suppression and plant growth promotion.  The presence of Penicillium in the root zone of wild F. thunbergii suggests that this genus may play a crucial role in enhancing the growth and disease resistance of this plant species. The dual functions of these Penicillium strains, including disease suppression and plant growth promotion, highlight their potential as beneficial microorganisms for F. thunbergii cultivation. This study's findings also underscore the importance of considering the absolute abundance of microorganisms in the root zone, rather than relying solely on relative abundance analysis, to effectively identify and utilize beneficial microorganisms for plant disease management and growth promotion.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: This paper explores the advancements in using nanomaterials to catalyze the degradation of mycotoxins, which are toxic substances produced by certain moulds. The research examines three types of nanomaterials: nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts. These nanomaterials are designed to break down mycotoxins into less toxic compounds, reducing their harm to humans and the environment. The study aims to provide a critical analysis of the effectiveness and potential applications of these nanomaterials in mycotoxin degradation.  The capacity of these nanomaterials to degrade mycotoxins highlights the complex and multifaceted relationships between moulds, nanomaterials, and environmental remediation. While moulds can be seen as pathogens, they can also be viewed as resources to be harnessed in the development of novel remediation technologies. The emergence of these technologies underscores the need to consider the material entanglements between human and nonhuman actors in shaping environmental outcomes.

title: Role of T-2 toxin in the modulation of oxidative homeostasis and immune function in three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin
source: Frontiers in Veterinary Science | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: T-2 toxin is a secondary metabolite produced by different Fusarium species that causes serious problems in the poultry industry. It can damage several organ systems, mainly by inhibiting protein synthesis, and is also likely to induce oxidative stress in cells. In this study, the adverse effects of T-2 toxin were investigated in magnetic three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. Cultures were treated with 100, 500, and 1,000 nM T-2 toxin for 48 and 72 h. The metabolic activity of the cells was determined using CCK-8 assay. To investigate the changes in the oxidative homeostasis, the levels of MDA, HSP27, and 8-OHdG were measured. To monitor immune response, the concentrations of IL-6 and 8 were determined. The metabolic activity of the cells decreased after the toxin treatments, but this decrease was alleviated after 72 h. Both MDA and HSP27 levels were significantly diminished by T-2 toxin after 48 h. The concentration of 8-OHdG was reduced by 72 h exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin. In the case of IL-6, the 1,000 nM T-2 toxin was able to decrease its levels after 48 and 72 h, whereas IL-8 levels were lowered after 72 h by all three toxin treatments. Overall, these resu
summary: The study investigated the effects of T-2 toxin, a secondary metabolite produced by certain Fusarium species, on chicken liver cells in a three-dimensional culture. T-2 toxin was found to decrease metabolic activity in cells, particularly after 48 hours of exposure. The toxin also reduced the levels of malondialdehyde, a marker of oxidative stress, and HSP27, a heat shock protein, after 48 hours. However, after 72 hours of exposure, the concentration of 8-OHdG, another marker of oxidative stress, was reduced only in cells treated with the lowest concentration of T-2 toxin. The study also found that T-2 toxin decreased the levels of IL-6 and IL-8, two cytokines involved in the immune response, after 48 and 72 hours of exposure.  The findings suggest that T-2 toxin can induce oxidative stress and compromise immune function in chicken liver cells. The study's results also highlight the potential for T-2 toxin to disrupt cellular homeostasis, particularly in the liver, a key organ for detoxification and metabolism. The entanglement of T-2 toxin's toxic effects with the cellular processes of oxidative homeostasis and immune function underscores the complex interplay between this mycotoxin and the biological systems it affects.

title: Nursing management of pulmonary mucormycosis with skin damage secondary to amphotericin B colloidal dispersion: a case report
source: Frontiers in Medicine | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionMucormycosis is a catastrophic fungal infection in immunocompromised patients and has a high mortality rate. Amphotericin B colloidal dispersions have demonstrated clinical efficacy in the treatment of mucormycosis; however, there is limited literature on the management of severe skin damage secondary to the extravasation of amphotericin B colloidal dispersions.Case presentationA 36-year-old diabetic woman with severe pulmonary mucormycosis developed skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion treatment via a peripheral vein. The medication was switched to a central vein, and nursing interventions, including silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress, successfully managed the injury. By day 155, the skin had completely healed with minimal residual pigmentation.ConclusionThis case report describes the management of a severe skin injury caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersion extravasation in an immunocompromised patient, carried out by bedside nurses.Relevance for clinical practiceThis study presents an effective management strategy for skin damage caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersions extravasation, emphasiz
summary: The case report documents a 36-year-old diabetic woman who developed severe skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of treatment with amphotericin B colloidal dispersion via a peripheral vein for pulmonary mucormycosis. The medication was switched to a central vein, and the skin injury was managed by bedside nurses using silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress. By day 155, the skin had completely healed with minimal residual pigmentation. This report highlights the effective management of a severe skin injury caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersion extravasation in an immune-weakened patient. The case demonstrates the importance of prompt intervention and the use of specific nursing interventions to mitigate the damage. The patient's skin damage, caused by the interaction of a pharmaceutical material (amphotericin B colloidal dispersion) and a compromised host (immune-weakened patient), underscores the complex and entangled nature of human-nonhuman relations in clinical settings.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Invasive fungal diseases (IFDs) are common and often fatal in severe burn patients due to skin barrier loss and immune dysfunction. However, current definitions of invasive mold infections are poorly adapted to this population. This study evaluated the characteristics of various diagnostic criteria and their combinations in relation to clinical outcomes in burn patients. We conducted a retrospective cohort study of all patients admitted to the Burn ICU from 2014 to 2023 with ≥15% total burn surface area and at least one sample sent to the mycology lab. Criteria included direct microscopy, culture (respiratory, skin, or tissue), species-specific quantitative PCR (qPCR) (Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium) on plasma/tissue/bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, and serum galactomannan. Among 276 patients, 489/6,184 samples were positive, including 281 skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) and 132 plasma specimens (qPCR). Positive diagnostic criteria ≥1 was found in 93 patients (33.7%): Aspergillus (25.7%), Mucorales (10.9%), and Fusarium (9.8%). Twenty-seven patients (9.8%) had ≥2 criteria involving ≥2 mold types. Mortality rose with the number of positive criteria: 12.7% (0), 10.7% (1, 2), 27.3% (3, 4), and 46.7% (≥5) (P < 0.001). Plasma qPCR was positive in 81.3% of Mucorales, 40% of Aspergillus, and 15.4% of Fusarium cases with skin involvement. Skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) combined with species-specific plasma qPCR enhance timely and reliable IFD diagnosis in burn patients. Mortality correlated with the number of positive criteria and coexistence of multiple mold species, underscoring the need for broad antifungal coverage and the value of multi-criteria diagnostics to guide treatment. IMPORTANCE Invasive mold infections are frequent and often fatal complications in patients with severe burns, occurring in up to 20% of cases with a total burn surface area exceeding 15%. Despite their severity, no standardized
summary: This paper reports on a retrospective cohort study of patients with severe burn injuries admitted to a Burn ICU between 2014 and 2023. The study evaluated the characteristics of various diagnostic criteria for invasive mold infections in this population, including direct microscopy, culture, species-specific quantitative polymerase chain reaction for Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium, and serum galactomannan. Among 276 patients, 489 out of 6,184 samples were positive, with Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium being the most common mold types identified. The number of positive diagnostic criteria was associated with increased mortality, with 46.7% of patients having 5 or more positive criteria experiencing mortality.   The study found that plasma quantitative polymerase chain reaction was a reliable method for detecting Mucorales infections, particularly in cases with skin involvement. The combination of skin biopsies and species-specific plasma quantitative polymerase chain reaction enhanced timely and reliable diagnosis of invasive mold infections in burn patients. The findings underscore the need for broad antifungal coverage and the value of multi-criteria diagnostics to guide treatment.  The study highlights the complex interplay between invasive mold infections and burn injuries, where the loss of skin barrier and immune dysfunction create an ideal environment for mold growth and infection. The diagnostic criteria evaluated in this study can be seen as a tool to navigate this complex material assemblage, where the same species that pose a threat to human health can also be vehicles for accumulation and adaptation. The reliance on multiple diagnostic criteria to guide treatment reflects the patchy and fragmented nature of the material environment in which invasive mold infections occur.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1), a potent mycotoxin frequently detected in improperly stored poultry feed, induces hepatic oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. Curcumin (CUR), a polyphenolic compound derived from Curcuma longa, exhibits strong antioxidant and anti‐inflammatory activities; however, its efficacy and mechanisms in mitigating AFB1‐induced hepatotoxicity in broilers remain unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the protective effects of dietary CUR supplementation on growth performance and liver health of broilers exposed to AFB1.
summary: This paper investigates the effects of aflatoxin B1 on liver health and growth performance in broilers, and whether dietary curcumin can alleviate these negative impacts. AFB1, a common contaminant in improperly stored poultry feed, causes oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. The researchers aimed to determine if CUR, a polyphenolic compound with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, could mitigate these effects. The study found that dietary CUR supplementation improved growth performance and reduced liver injury in broilers exposed to AFB1. This was attributed to CUR's activation of the nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 pathway and inhibition of the NOD-like receptor protein 3 inflammasome.   The capacity of CUR to counteract the negative effects of AFB1 highlights the complex interplay between dietary components and environmental toxins in poultry health. The dual role of CUR as a therapeutic agent and a nutritional supplement underscores the material entanglements between human and nonhuman actors in the poultry industry.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The World Health Organization has flagged the rise of drug resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus as a critical concern. Elevated mutation rates in this pathogen contribute to the rapid development of resistance, complicating treatment efforts. We conducted a study on the prevalence of azole resistance among clinical A. fumigatus isolates in the Netherlands from 1994 to 2022 and identified 34 cyp51A variants. To investigate the impact of individual single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and combinations thereof on the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes, we focused on novel, recent mutations and explored the effects of SNPs L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S and the combination of the mutations TR34/L98H, TR34/L98H/T289A/G448S, and TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S on azole affinity and susceptibility. We created the three-dimensional protein model of the Cyp51A protein with azoles, and the mutation was introduced to the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain by the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique. Finally, in vitro susceptibility testing of A. fumigatus strains carrying the mutations was conducted to confirm the azole phenotypes observed in clinical isolates. The MICs of all four azoles against the mutated cyp51A strains, which harbored combination mutations, were higher than those of the wild type, with highly elevated MICs of itraconazole, voriconazole, and isavuconazole. Genotypes TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S mutant showed a consistent phenotype to the clinical strains, which are highly resistant to voriconazole but susceptible to itraconazole. In this study, we show that molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene correlate to the structure–function relationship of in vitro phenotype.
summary: The study examined the characteristics of individual and combined single-nucleotide polymorphisms (single nucleotide polymorphisms) in the cyp51A gene of Aspergillus fumigatus, a pathogen responsible for azole resistance. The researchers identified 34 cyp51A variants among clinical isolates in the Netherlands from 1994 to 2022. They focused on four specific single nucleotide polymorphisms - L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S - and their combinations, including TR34/L98H, TR34/L98H/T289A/G448S, and TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S. The study used the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique to introduce these mutations into the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain, and then conducted laboratory-based susceptibility testing to confirm the azole observable traits observed in clinical isolates. The results showed that the mutated strains had higher minimum inhibitory concentrations of four azoles compared to the wild-type strain, with highly elevated minimum inhibitory concentrations of itraconazole, voriconazole, and isavuconazole. The combination mutation TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S showed a consistent observable trait profile with clinical strains, which are highly resistant to voriconazole but susceptible to itraconazole. The study's findings suggest that molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene can predict the structure-function relationship of laboratory-based observable traits.  The study highlights the complex relationship between Aspergillus fumigatus and azole resistance, where molecular adaptations can both compromise and exploit the pathogen's interaction with its environment. The identification of specific single nucleotide polymorphisms and their combinations as drivers of azole resistance underscores the need for targeted treatment strategies that account for the nuanced material entanglements between the pathogen, the drug, and the host.

title: Antifungal Activity and Resistance Risk of Cyclobutrifluram against Fusarium solani, the Causal Agent of Peanut Root Rot
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Peanut root rot (PRR), caused by Fusarium solani, is a common and destructive disease. Cyclobutrifluram exhibits antifungal activity against Fusarium spp., yet its bioactivity and resistance risk against F. solani remain unclear. In this study, the EC50 values of cyclobutrifluram against 155 F. solani strains ranged from 0.0279 to 0.1102 μg/mL, with a mean of 0.0513 ± 0.0170 μg/mL. Treatment with cyclobutrifluram significantly inhibited conidial production and germination, reduced succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) activity, increased hyphal branching, and shortened the distance between septa or cell nuclei. Cyclobutrifluram provided excellent control over PRR. Seven laboratory-generated cyclobutrifluram-resistant mutants showed no or slight fitness penalties and exhibited positive cross-resistance only with pydiflumetofen, indicating a moderate-to-high resistance risk. Resistance to cyclobutrifluram in F. solani was conferred by four SDH substitutions (FsSdhBH248Y, FsSdhC1A83V, FsSdhC2A85V, and FsSdhDD184G), which was confirmed by molecular docking and gene replacement. This study provides crucial insights for developing effective control strategies to manage PRR.
summary: This paper documents the antifungal activity of cyclobutrifluram against Fusarium solani, a fungus that causes peanut root rot. The study found that cyclobutrifluram effectively inhibited conidial production and germination, reduced succinate dehydrogenase activity, increased hyphal branching, and shortened the distance between septa or cell nuclei in F. solani. The EC50 values of cyclobutrifluram against 155 F. solani strains ranged from 0.0279 to 0.1102 μg/mL, with a mean of 0.0513 ± 0.0170 μg/mL. However, the development of resistance to cyclobutrifluram in F. solani is a concern, as seven laboratory-generated mutants showed no or slight fitness penalties and exhibited positive cross-resistance with pydiflumetofen. Resistance to cyclobutrifluram was conferred by four succinate dehydrogenase substitutions, which was confirmed by molecular docking and gene replacement.  the need for effective control strategies to manage PRR.  The findings of this study reveal the complex relationship between cyclobutrifluram and F. solani, where the fungicide's antifungal activity is matched by the pathogen's capacity to adapt and develop resistance. This entanglement underscores the dynamic interplay between human interventions and ecological responses in the face of agricultural disease management.

title: Efficacy of Ipflufenoquin against Strawberry Gray Mold: Insights from AlphaFold- Based Structural Modeling and Genome-Wide Transcriptomic Analysis
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gray mold caused by Botrytis cinerea significantly threatens strawberry production. This study evaluated the efficacy of ipflufenoquin, a novel dihydroorotate dehydrogenase (DHODH) inhibitor, against fungal pathogens isolated from Korean strawberry fields in 2023. Ipflufenoquin demonstrated a high in vitro sensitivity to B. cinerea and broad activity against other pathogens. Fruit and greenhouse trials confirmed its robust control of gray mold, including strains resistant to multiple fungicide classes. However, treatment shifted the fungal community, promoting less sensitive genera, such as Cladosporium and Rhizopus. Structural modeling with AlphaFold2 and molecular docking confirmed that ipflufenoquin binds to the quinone binding tunnel of DHODH, correlating binding affinity with susceptibility. Additionally, RNA-seq analysis revealed that ipflufenoquin suppresses primary metabolic pathways while triggering a robust stress response, up-regulating detoxification and efflux transporter genes. This integrated study confirms the efficacy of ipflufenoquin against gray mold and elucidates its molecular impacts, offering essential data for sustainable management strategies.
summary: Gray mold caused by Botrytis cinerea significantly threatens strawberry production. This study evaluated the efficacy of ipflufenoquin, a novel dihydroorotate dehydrogenase inhibitor, against fungal pathogens isolated from Korean strawberry fields in 2023. Ipflufenoquin demonstrated a high laboratory-based sensitivity to B. cinerea and broad activity against other pathogens. Fruit and greenhouse trials confirmed its robust control of gray mold, including strains resistant to multiple fungicide classes. However, treatment shifted the fungal community, promoting less sensitive genera, such as Cladosporium and Rhizopus. Structural modeling with AlphaFold2 and molecular docking confirmed that ipflufenoquin binds to the quinone binding tunnel of dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, correlating binding affinity with susceptibility. Additionally, RNA-seq analysis revealed that ipflufenoquin suppresses primary metabolic pathways while triggering a robust stress response, up-regulating detoxification and efflux transporter genes. This integrated study confirms the efficacy of ipflufenoquin against gray mold and elucidates its molecular impacts, offering essential data for sustainable management strategies.  The findings of this study highlight the dual role of ipflufenoquin as both a pathogen control agent and a disruptor of the fungal community. By targeting the dihydroorotate dehydrogenase enzyme, ipflufenoquin effectively controls gray mold, but also promotes the growth of less sensitive fungal genera, underscoring the complex dynamics of fungal interactions and the need for integrated management strategies that consider the broader ecological implications of pathogen control.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The substantial increase in fungal diseases, the limited availability of antifungal drugs, and rising resistance to existing treatments highlight the urgent need for developing novel antifungal drugs. Natural products, known for their diverse bioactivities and unique structures, remain critical sources for antifungal drug discovery. In this study, we aimed to identify novel antifungal compounds from soil microbes and isolated a novel 28-membered polyene macrolide, compound 1 , from Kitasatospora melanogena . This compound demonstrated potent antifungal activity, with MICs of 4–16 μg/mL against Aspergillus fumigatus , Aspergillus flavus , Candida albicans , and Cryptococcus neoformans . Treatment with compound 1 led to significant growth reduction and disruption of the cell wall and membrane in A. fumigatus compared to the wild-type. To understand the underlying mechanism, we performed a transcriptomic analysis of A. fumigatus exposed to compound 1 , revealing a substantial downregulation of genes involved in cell wall and membrane biogenesis, as well as those encoding integral membrane proteins and multidrug transporters. Additionally, compound 1 induced oxidative stress, leading to elevated reactive oxygen species levels. These multifaceted mechanisms highlight the potential of K. melanogena natural products in the development of novel antifungal agents. IMPORTANCE Fungal infections cause substantial morbidity and mortality worldwide, yet current treatments are limited and increasingly undermined by resistance. Natural products remain a proven source of antifungal agents, but few new scaffolds have been introduced in recent decades. We identified a novel polyene macrolide from Kitasatospora melanogena with potent activity against major fungal pathogens. This compound disrupts both the fungal cell wall and membrane while inducing oxidative stress, revealing a multifaceted mechanism of action. Our findings highlight soil microbes as valuable reservoirs for a
summary: Researchers have identified a novel compound, isolated from soil microbes of the species Kitasatospora melanogena, which demonstrates potent antifungal activity against several fungal pathogens, including Aspergillus fumigatus. The compound, a 28-membered polyene macrolide, exhibits minimum inhibitory concentrations of 4-16 micrograms per milliliter against Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus flavus, Candida albicans, and Cryptococcus neoformans. When exposed to this compound, Aspergillus fumigatus undergoes significant growth reduction and disruption of its cell wall and membrane. gene-expression analysis analysis reveals that the compound downregulates genes involved in cell wall and membrane biogenesis, as well as those encoding integral membrane proteins and multidrug transporters. Furthermore, the compound induces oxidative stress, leading to elevated levels of reactive oxygen species.  This novel compound highlights the potential of soil microbes as reservoirs for antifungal agents, and its multifaceted mechanism of action suggests that it could be a valuable resource for developing new treatments against fungal infections. The findings also underscore the urgent need for developing novel antifungal drugs, given the limited availability of existing treatments and the rising resistance to them.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: This study investigated how doping-modified copper sulfide (CuS) micronanoparticles (MNPs) influence tomato resistance against fungal pathogens. Three cuboidal CuS MNPs─undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS)─were foliarly applied to Fusarium-infected plants in a greenhouse study. Fe-CuS led to the highest Cu accumulation in leaves─15.7 and 158.4% higher than undoped CuS and Ce-CuS, respectively, likely due to its positive charge facilitating stronger electrostatic interactions and more efficient NPs uptake. Compared to the untreated control, the Fe-CuS foliar application resulted in a 487.7% increase in shoot biomass and a 36.8% reduction in wilt damage through activation of jasmonic acid/ethylene signaling, indicating a dual role of CuS MNPs as both a micronutrient carrier and an immune stimulant. Importantly, copper amine oxidases (CuAOs) activation may link Cu homeostasis to stress-induced H2O2 production, indicating a novel mechanism for nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity. These findings underscore the significant potential for CuS MNPs as an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides, though long-term environmental behavior and life cycle impacts warrant further evaluation.
summary: This paper investigated the effects of doping-modified copper sulfide (CuS) micronanoparticles (MNPs) on tomato resistance against fungal pathogens. Three types of CuS MNPs - undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS) - were applied to Fusarium-infected tomato plants in a greenhouse study. The iron-doped CuS MNPs (Fe-CuS) led to the highest accumulation of copper in leaves, which was likely due to its positive charge facilitating stronger electrostatic interactions and more efficient uptake. The Fe-CuS application resulted in a significant increase in shoot biomass and a reduction in wilt damage through the activation of jasmonic acid/ethylene signaling. This suggests that CuS MNPs can act as both micronutrient carriers and immune stimulants. The study also found that copper amine oxidases (CuAOs) activation may link copper homeostasis to stress-induced H2O2 production, indicating a novel mechanism for nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity. These findings have significant potential for CuS MNPs as an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides, but further evaluation of their long-term environmental behavior and life cycle impacts is warranted.  The entanglement of CuS MNPs with tomato plants' defense mechanisms reveals a complex interplay between micronutrient supply and immune stimulation. While CuS MNPs can induce a strong defense response against fungal pathogens, their potential environmental impacts and long-term effects on plant health require careful consideration.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Chemical fungicides act by targeting specific proteins or pathways, known as modes of action (MoAs). In this study, we established a systematic screening platform using Fusarium graminearum gene knockout mutants to evaluate the efficacy of fungicides and identify novel antifungal compounds. Target genes corresponding to major fungicide classes were deleted by homologous recombination, and the resulting mutants exhibited altered sensitivity to the corresponding fungicides compared with the wild-type strain. Deletion of genes encoding known fungicide targets revealed distinct sensitivity profiles, supporting MoA prediction. Using the platform that detects sensitivity differences through OD₆₀₀ changes, we examined a chemical library of 2,704 small molecules and identified 8 compounds with activity likely involved in the osmotic signal transduction pathway. Several of these compounds exhibited previously unreported antifungal activity, underscoring their potential as novel scaffolds for future development. Collectively, this platform provides a robust, mechanism-informed system for antifungal discovery, with broad applicability to synthetic agents, natural products, and biocontrol metabolites. IMPORTANCE This study provides a perspective on developing strategies to manage fungal pathogens with implications for agriculture and food security. The effectiveness of current fungicides is increasingly limited by resistance, narrow target ranges, and environmental concerns. By combining genetic approaches with chemical screening, this work offers a more systematic way to identify candidate antifungal agents and better understand their possible mechanisms. The framework may also be adapted for use in other areas, including medical and veterinary applications, suggesting potential broader applicability. In addition, the emphasis on exploring new molecular scaffolds supports efforts to develop more sustainable and long-term disease management strategies. Overall, this st
summary: This paper presents a systematic screening platform for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum, a fungal pathogen. The researchers used gene knockout mutants to evaluate the efficacy of fungicides and identify new compounds. They deleted genes corresponding to major fungicide classes and observed altered sensitivity to the corresponding fungicides in the resulting mutants. The study identified 8 compounds with activity likely involved in the osmotic signal transduction pathway, several of which exhibited previously unreported antifungal activity. These compounds have potential as novel scaffolds for future development. The platform developed in this study provides a robust, mechanism-informed system for antifungal discovery, with broad applicability to synthetic agents, natural products, and biocontrol metabolites. This research contributes to developing strategies to manage fungal pathogens, particularly in agriculture and food security, where the effectiveness of current fungicides is increasingly limited by resistance and environmental concerns.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Lipin, a phosphatidic acid phosphatase, catalyzes the conversion of phosphatidic acid to diacylglycerol, a key step in triacylglycerol (TAG) biosynthesis, and acts as a transcriptional coregulator of lipid metabolism. In this study, the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) was overexpressed in Mucor circinelloides WJ11 to evaluate its impact on lipid accumulation under submerged (SmF) and solid-state fermentation (SSF). Under SSF, McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight by 19% in spores and 36.9% in mycelia compared to the control strain. Total fatty acid (TFA) content increased by 35.7% in mycelia, while in spores it increased from 10% to 18% of dry cell weight, indicating a substantial enhancement in lipid yield. Fatty acid profiling showed elevated proportions of C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3 and a reduced C18:1 content. RT-qPCR indicated that McLipin expression peaked at 24 h under SSF, coinciding with upregulation of ACC, FAS, cME, and NADPH-generating genes. These results suggest that McLipin overexpression reprograms lipid metabolism, significantly enhancing TAG biosynthesis under SSF for potential industrial lipid production.
summary: The research signal reports on the overexpression of the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) in the oleaginous fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 to enhance lipid accumulation. This study found that under static solid cultivation, McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight by 19% in spores and 36.9% in mycelia compared to the control strain. The total fatty acid content also increased by 35.7% in mycelia, with a substantial enhancement in lipid yield. Fatty acid profiling showed elevated proportions of C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3 and a reduced C18:1 content. The results suggest that McLipin overexpression reprograms lipid metabolism, significantly enhancing triacylglycerol biosynthesis under solid-state fermentation for potential industrial lipid production.   The findings indicate a potential industrial application of Mucor circinelloides WJ11 in lipid production, where the overexpression of McLipin enhances lipid accumulation. However, the results also highlight the complexity of lipid metabolism in fungi, where the overexpression of a single gene can have a significant impact on the production of different fatty acids.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Aspergillus infection poses a major clinical challenge, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, with invasive diseases associated with high mortality. While Aspergillus fumigatus remains the predominant species causing human infections, recent studies highlight the growing clinical significance of lesser-known and cryptic Aspergillus species, which often exhibit reduced susceptibility to standard antifungal therapies. In this study, we analyzed 196 clinical Aspergillus isolates from 107 patients treated at the NIH Clinical Center between 2019 and 2022. A total of 38 Aspergillus species across 11 taxonomic sections were identified, with non-fumigatus and cryptic species accounting for 77.1% of all isolates. The most frequently recovered species were A. fumigatus sensu stricto (22.9%), A. sydowii (8.7%), A. calidoustus (7.1%), A. nidulans (6.6%), A. tanneri (6.1%), and A. terreus (5.6%). Species-level identification was achieved in 43% of isolates using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). In contrast, PCR sequencing confirmed species identity in over 88% of isolates by targeting the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of rDNA, 81% using the β-tubulin gene, and 68% using the calmodulin gene. The most common underlying clinical conditions among patients were bronchiectasis (35%), chronic granulomatous disease (22%), and pulmonary non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection (17%). Out of 107 patients, eight died (8/107, 7.5%); six of these deaths occurred in patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) and two in patients with RAG1 deficiency. Antifungal susceptibility testing showed that olorofim had the lowest minimal inhibitory concentrations across species. In contrast, the activity of triazoles and amphotericin B was variable, particularly against A. tanneri, A. calidoustus, and A. sydowii. This study presents one of the largest species-level data sets of Aspergillus isolates to date, und
summary: This paper analyzed 196 clinical Aspergillus isolates from 107 patients treated at the NIH Clinical Center between 2019 and 2022. The isolates belonged to 38 different Aspergillus species across 11 taxonomic sections, with non-fumigatus and cryptic species making up 77.1% of all isolates. The most commonly recovered species were Aspergillus fumigatus sensu stricto, Aspergillus sydowii, Aspergillus calidoustus, Aspergillus nidulans, Aspergillus tanneri, and Aspergillus terreus. Species-level identification was achieved in 43% of isolates using a technique called matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry, while polymerase chain reaction sequencing confirmed species identity in over 88% of isolates.  The study found that patients with underlying clinical conditions such as bronchiectasis, chronic granulomatous disease, and pulmonary non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection were more likely to be infected with Aspergillus. Eight patients died, with six of these deaths occurring in patients with chronic granulomatous disease. Antifungal susceptibility testing showed that olorofim had the lowest minimal inhibitory concentrations across species, while the activity of triazoles and amphotericin B was variable, particularly against certain species such as Aspergillus tanneri and Aspergillus calidoustus.  The findings of this study highlight the diversity of Aspergillus species that can cause human infections, and the need for more effective antifungal therapies, particularly against species that are resistant to standard treatments. The study's emphasis on species-level identification and antifungal susceptibility testing underscores the importance of targeted approaches to diagnosing and treating Aspergillus infections. Through its comprehensive analysis of clinical Aspergillus isolates, this study contributes to our understanding of the complex relationships between humans, Aspergillus species, and the environment, revealing the duality of these organisms as both pathogens and potential resources for accumulation.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP) toxin, has been reported in several fungal species, but its distribution remains unclear. We analyzed 140 clinical isolates from two major hospitals using HPLC and LC-MS/MS to assess gliotoxin production. Gliotoxin was detected only in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates, with no production observed in any other species under multiple culture conditions. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed distinct ETP-related pathways in non-A. fumigatus species, including aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. These findings clarify species-specific ETP profiles and confirm A. fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the isolates examined.
summary: This paper investigated the production of gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine toxin, in clinical fungal isolates from two major hospitals. The researchers analyzed 140 isolates using high-performance liquid chromatography and liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry to detect gliotoxin production. They found that gliotoxin was produced only by Aspergillus fumigatus isolates, with no production observed in any other species under multiple culture conditions. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed distinct epipolythiodioxopiperazine-related pathways in non-A. fumigatus species, such as aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. These findings clarify the species-specific epipolythiodioxopiperazine profiles and confirm A. fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the examined isolates.  The capacity of Aspergillus fumigatus to produce gliotoxin stands in contrast to the presence of epipolythiodioxopiperazine-related pathways in other fungal species, which fail to produce this toxin. This highlights the complex material entanglements between fungal species and their metabolic capabilities, underscoring the need for a nuanced understanding of the diverse relationships between microorganisms and their environments.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Eight new decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, pyrrospirones R-Y (1-8), together with 13 known analogues (9-21) were isolated from the marine-derived fungal strain Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. Their structures were determined by extensive spectroscopic analysis, and their absolute configurations were established by quantum chemical calculations of electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, by a comparison of experimental ECD spectra, or by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Compound 1 rarely contains an oxime hydroxy with a 6/5/6/5/6/13 polycyclic system. A plausible biosynthetic pathway for 1 and 2 was proposed. Biologically, compounds 1, 4, 6, 8, 10-12, 14-15, 18-19, and 21 had cytotoxicity against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116 with IC50 values of 7.3-79.3 μM, and 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21 also showed significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria with MIC values of 1.6-13.0 μg/mL. Their structure-bioactivity relationship was also discussed.
summary: This paper reports on the isolation and characterization of eight new decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, pyrrospirones R-Y (1-8), along with 13 known analogues (9-21), from the marine-derived fungal strain Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. The structures of these compounds were determined through extensive spectroscopic analysis, and their absolute configurations were established through quantum chemical calculations and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Compound 1, a decahydrofluorene-class alkaloid, contains an oxime hydroxy with a 6/5/6/5/6/13 polycyclic system. A plausible biosynthetic pathway for compounds 1 and 2 was proposed. The isolated compounds showed varying levels of toxicity to cells against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116, with IC50 values ranging from 7.3-79.3 μM. Compounds 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21 also demonstrated significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria, with minimum inhibitory concentration values ranging from 1.6-13.0 μg/mL.  The findings of this study highlight the potential of marine-derived fungi as sources of bioactive compounds with antimicrobial and cell-damaging properties. The diverse structures and bioactivities of the isolated compounds suggest complex relationships between their chemical structures and biological activities. The identification of compounds with antimicrobial properties, such as compounds 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21, may have implications for the development of novel antifungal and antibacterial treatments.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Mold identification in clinical diagnostics is traditionally labor-intensive and is dependent on expert interpretation. MoldVision is a deep-learning approach that uses smartphone images of mold cultures to automate identification. We analyzed 161 clinical isolates across four common mold genera: Penicillium spp., Aspergillus spp. (with A. flavus and A. fumigatus), Fusarium spp., and Cladosporium spp. Daily images were captured from the top and bottom of culture plates over 5 days using a standardized smartphone setup, generating over 4,000 images. We trained three variations of Visual Geometry Group 16 (VGG16) convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and benchmarked the best-performing model (VGG16 with dual classification heads) against LightGBM models trained on pre-extracted features and human expert assessments at various time points. The best-performing VGG16 model achieved a mean (SD) AUROC of 92.7% ± 1.8% and sensitivity of 68.7% ± 2.6% across all species. Here, the performance in identifying Cladosporium spp. was best (AUROC of 99.9% ± 0.1%, fivefold cross-validation mean and SD). Regarding the evaluations over time, early-stage classification (days 1–2) was challenging (F1-score 38.8% ± 3.5% across all species) but improved significantly on days 3–5 (F1 92.1% ± 2.8% across all species). Compared to experts, MoldVision consistently showed superior performance, particularly in mature cultures, detecting subtle morphological features earlier and more accurately. Our results demonstrate that CNNs integrated with low-cost smartphone imaging can reliably classify mold species in routine diagnostics, outperforming human experts in many cases. This approach offers a practical and scalable solution for laboratories lacking specialized mycology expertise, especially in resource-limited settings. IMPORTANCE Timely, accurate mold identification can save lives, yet today it often requires days of growth and scarce expert time. MoldVision offers a practical alterna
summary: This paper reports on the development of a deep-learning approach called MoldVision, which uses smartphone images of mold cultures to automate mold identification in clinical diagnostics. Researchers analyzed 161 clinical isolates across four common mold genera: Penicillium spp., Aspergillus spp., Fusarium spp., and Cladosporium spp. They captured over 4,000 images of these isolates using a standardized smartphone setup and trained a convolutional neural network to identify the mold species. The best-performing model achieved a mean area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 92.7% and sensitivity of 68.7% across all species. The model performed particularly well in identifying Cladosporium spp. with an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 99.9%.  the model's performance improved significantly over time, with earlier-stage classification being challenging but improving on days 3-5. Compared to human experts, MoldVision consistently showed superior performance, particularly in mature cultures, detecting subtle morphological features earlier and more accurately. This approach offers a practical and scalable solution for laboratories lacking specialized mycology expertise, especially in resource-limited settings.  The development of MoldVision highlights the complex relationship between mold identification and technological advancements, where a pathogen can also be a resource for diagnosis. The capacity of mold cultures to be rapidly imaged and analyzed using low-cost smartphone technology underscores the duality of mold as both a threat and a tool for diagnostics, particularly in resource-limited settings.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Nitric oxide (NO) is an important biological signaling molecule. S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR), a master regulator of NO signaling, regulates various biological processes. However, little is known about the role of GSNOR in Aspergillus flavus. Here, we identified a gene encoding GSNOR in this aflatoxigenic fungus and demonstrated that GSNOR shows activity during the critical life cycle stages, including spore germination, hyphal growth, and conidiogenesis. We found that GSNOR plays a crucial role in NO homeostasis, as GSNOR deletion resulted in significantly elevated NO levels and heightened sensitivity to exogenous NO stress. GSNOR also participated in multiple biological processes in A. flavus; for that, GSNOR deletion impaired conidia germination, reduced growth, decreased conidiogenesis and sclerotial development, attenuated virulence on kernels, and notably decreased aflatoxin production. Furthermore, we demonstrated that GSNOR is important for reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance, as its deletion significantly elevated mycelial ROS levels and made the strain more sensitive to oxidative stress. IMPORTANCE Aspergillus flavus is a notorious saprophytic filamentous fungus, with its production of carcinogenic aflatoxins posing serious threats to food safety and human health. Aflatoxin contamination prevention and control have long been a global challenge. In previous studies, we observed that nitric oxide (NO) significantly inhibits the aflatoxin production by A. flavus. This study further investigated the role of the key regulatory enzyme S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) in the NO signaling pathway. Our findings indicate that GSNOR is crucial for maintaining both NO homeostasis and reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance and plays an essential role in fungal development, pathogenicity, and aflatoxin biosynthesis. These results highlight the potential of targeting components in the NO signaling pathway, such as GSNOR, as a novel strategy for
summary: The research in this paper identifies a gene encoding S-nitrosoglutathione reductase in the aflatoxigenic fungus Aspergillus flavus. It is found that S-nitrosoglutathione reductase shows activity during the critical life cycle stages of A. flavus, including spore germination, hyphal growth, and conidiogenesis. Deletion of the S-nitrosoglutathione reductase gene resulted in significantly elevated nitric oxide levels and heightened sensitivity to exogenous nitric oxide stress in A. flavus. Furthermore, S-nitrosoglutathione reductase deletion impaired conidia germination, reduced growth, decreased conidiogenesis and sclerotial development, attenuated disease-causing ability on kernels, and notably decreased aflatoxin production. The study also found that S-nitrosoglutathione reductase is important for reactive oxygen species balance, as its deletion significantly elevated mycelial reactive oxygen species levels and made the strain more sensitive to oxidative stress. This research highlights the potential of targeting components in the nitric oxide signaling pathway, such as S-nitrosoglutathione reductase, as a novel strategy for controlling aflatoxin production in A. flavus.  The findings of this study reveal the dual role of S-nitrosoglutathione reductase in maintaining both nitric oxide homeostasis and reactive oxygen species balance in A. flavus. The enzyme's involvement in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity underscores its importance in fungal development and disease-causing ability. The discovery of S-nitrosoglutathione reductase's essential function in A. flavus also raises questions about the broader implications of nitric oxide signaling in fungal biology and its potential as a target for novel antifungal strategies.
